dialogs.original: Boult!
dialogs.translated: Boult!

dialogs.original: Sir?
dialogs.translated: Sir?

dialogs.original: Search the market narrowly; Mytilene is full ofgallants. We lost too much money this mart by beingtoo wenchless.
dialogs.translated: Search the market carefully. Mytilene is full of young men. We lost too much money this season because we didn't have enough girls.

dialogs.original: We were never so much out of creatures.   We have but    poor three, and they can do no more than they can    do;   and they with continual action are even as good as rotten.
dialogs.translated: We've never had such a shortage of creatures. We only have three, and they can only do what they can do. And they've worked so much they're as good as rotten.

dialogs.original: Therefore let's have fresh ones, whate'er we pay for    them.   If there be not a conscience to be used in    every trade, we shall never prosper.
dialogs.translated: So, let's get some fresh ones, no matter what we have to pay for them. If we don't put any heart into this business we'll never succeed.

dialogs.original: Thou sayest true: 'tis not our bringing up of poorbastards,as, I think, I have brought up some eleven
dialogs.translated: You're right. Of course, we've brought up some bastards . . . I've brought up at least eleven, I think

dialogs.original: Ay, to eleven; and brought them down again. Butshall I search the market?
dialogs.translated: Yeah, it was eleven, and we brought them down again! But should I search the market?

dialogs.original: What else, man? The stuff we have, a strong windwill blow it to pieces, they are so pitifully sodden.
dialogs.translated: What else can we do? The girls we have are so pitiful, a strong wind would blow them all to pieces.

dialogs.original: Thou sayest true; they're too unwholesome, o'    conscience.   The poor Transylvanian is dead, that    lay with the little baggage.
dialogs.translated: You're right; they're a mess, truth be told. The poor Transylvanian girl is deadthe one that slept with that guy with the tiny junk.

dialogs.original: Ay, she quickly pooped him; she made him roast-meatfor worms. But I'll go search the market.
dialogs.translated: Yeah, and she gave him whatever she had; he's food for worms now! But I'll go search the market.

dialogs.original: Three or four thousand chequins were as pretty aproportion to live quietly, and so give over.
dialogs.translated: Three or four thousand gold coins is all we need to retire quietly and give up the business.

dialogs.original: Why to give over, I pray you? is it a shame to getwhen we are old?
dialogs.translated: Why would we give it up? Is there anything wrong with working while we're old?

dialogs.original: O, our credit comes not in like the commodity, nor    the commodity wages not with the danger:   therefore,    if in our youths we could pick up some pretty    estate, 'twere not amiss to keep our door hatched.    Besides, the sore terms we stand upon with the gods    will be strong with us for giving over.
dialogs.translated: Our credit's not as good as our property, and our property hasn't held up well. When we were young we could pick up lots of young girls, and it was easy to keep a roof over our heads. Besides, the fact that we're in the gods' bad books is reason enough to retire.

dialogs.original: Come, other sorts offend as well as we.
dialogs.translated: Oh, come on. Loads of people do as much evil as we do.

dialogs.original: As well as we! ay, and better too; we offend worse.    Neither is our profession any trade; it's no    calling. But here comes Boult.
dialogs.translated: As much as we do? But our evil is worse. And our profession isn't really a "trade" or a "calling." But here comes Boult.

dialogs.original: [To MARINA]  Come your ways. My masters, you sayshe's a virgin?
dialogs.translated: [To MARINA] Hurry up, now. [To the PIRATES] So, guys, you say she's a virgin?

dialogs.original: O, sir, we doubt it not.
dialogs.translated: Oh, sir, we have no doubt.

dialogs.original: Master, I have gone through for this piece, you see:if you like her, so; if not, I have lost my earnest.
dialogs.translated: Master, I've paid through the nose for this one. If you like her, good. If not, I've lost my bet.

dialogs.original: Boult, has she any qualities?
dialogs.translated: Boult, what are her assets?

dialogs.original: She has a good face, speaks well, and has excellentgood clothes: there's no further necessity ofqualities can make her be refused.
dialogs.translated: She has a good face, speaks well, and has really nice clothes. There's nothing about her that would make you dislike her.

dialogs.original: What's her price, Boult?
dialogs.translated: What's her price, Boult?

dialogs.original: I cannot be bated one doit of a thousand pieces.
dialogs.translated: I can't get her for a cent less than a thousand gold coins.

dialogs.original: Well, follow me, my masters, you shall have your    money presently.   Wife, take her in; instruct her    what she has to do, that she may not be raw in her    entertainment.
dialogs.translated: Well, follow me, guys. You'll get your money shortly. [To BAWD] Wife, take her in. Teach her what she has to do so she's not caught unawares her first time.

dialogs.original: Boult, take you the marks of her, the colour of her    hair, complexion, height, age, with warrant of her    virginity; and cry 'He that will give most shall    have her first.'   Such a maidenhead were no cheap    thing, if men were as they have been. Get this done    as I command you.
dialogs.translated: Boult, write a full report of her: the color of her hair, complexion, height, age, with a guarantee of her virginity, and cry, "Whoever pays the most can have her first." If I know men, a virginity like this won't go cheap. Do exactly as I say.

dialogs.original: Performance shall follow.
dialogs.translated: I'll take care of it.

dialogs.original: Alack that Leonine was so slack, so slow!    He should have struck, not spoke;   or that these pirates,    Not enough barbarous, had not o'erboard thrown me    For to seek my mother!
dialogs.translated: If only Leonine hadn't been so slow! He should have killed me instead of talking so much. Or if only the pirates (as if they weren't barbarous enough) had thrown me overboard, to go after my mother!

dialogs.original: Why lament you, pretty one?
dialogs.translated: Why are you crying, pretty girl?

dialogs.original: That I am pretty.
dialogs.translated: Because I'm pretty.

dialogs.original: Come, the gods have done their part in you.
dialogs.translated: Come on, the gods have blessed you.

dialogs.original: I accuse them not.
dialogs.translated: I'm not accusing them.

dialogs.original: You are light into my hands, where you are like to live.
dialogs.translated: You've come into my hands now, where you're likely to live.

dialogs.original: The more my faultTo scape his hands where I was like to die.
dialogs.translated: Which makes it even worse that I escaped Leonine's hands, where I might have died.

dialogs.original: Ay, and you shall live in pleasure.
dialogs.translated: Oh, but you'll live in pleasure.

dialogs.original: No.
dialogs.translated: No.

dialogs.original: Yes, indeed shall you, and taste gentlemen of allfashions: you shall fare well; you shall have thedifference of all complexions. What! do you stop your ears?
dialogs.translated: Yes, you will, and you'll taste all different kinds of gentlemen. You'll do well! You'll have all sorts. What? Why are you covering your ears?

dialogs.original: Are you a woman?
dialogs.translated: Are you a woman?

dialogs.original: What would you have me be, an I be not a woman?
dialogs.translated: What would you rather me be, if not a woman?

dialogs.original: An honest woman, or not a woman.
dialogs.translated: A good woman, or not a woman at all.

dialogs.original: Marry, whip thee, gosling: I think I shall have    something to do with you.   Come, you're a young    foolish sapling, and must be bowed as I would have    you.
dialogs.translated: Shut your mouth, girl. I think I'll have to do something about you. You're young and naive and you'll have to be broken as I would have you.

dialogs.original: The gods defend me!
dialogs.translated: May the gods protect me!

dialogs.original: If it please the gods to defend you by men, then menmust comfort you, men must feed you, men must stiryou up. Boult's returned.
dialogs.translated: If it pleases the gods to protect you through men, then men will comfort you, feed you, sleep with you. Boult's back.

dialogs.original: Now, sir, hast thou cried her through the market?
dialogs.translated: Have you spread the word about her all over the market?

dialogs.original: I have cried her almost to the number of her hairs;I have drawn her picture with my voice.
dialogs.translated: I've described her down to every last hair. I've drawn a picture of her with my voice.

dialogs.original: And I prithee tell me, how dost thou find theinclination of the people, especially of the younger sort?
dialogs.translated: And please, tell me: how do people seem to be reacting, especially the younger ones?

dialogs.original: 'Faith, they listened to me as they would have    hearkened to their father's testament.   There was a    Spaniard's mouth so watered, that he went to bed to    her very description.
dialogs.translated: Well, they listened to me as closely as they would to their own father's will being read. There was a Spanish guy whose mouth watered so much, he went to masturbate off just the description of her.

dialogs.original: We shall have him here to-morrow with his best ruff on.
dialogs.translated: I'm sure he'll be here tomorrow in his best clothes.

dialogs.original: To-night, to-night. But, mistress, do you know theFrench knight that cowers i' the hams?
dialogs.translated: Tonight, tonight. But, mistress, do you know the French guy who works as a butcher?

dialogs.original: Who, Monsieur Veroles?
dialogs.translated: Who, Mr. Syphilis?

dialogs.original: Ay, he: he offered to cut a caper at theproclamation; but he made a groan at it, and sworehe would see her to-morrow.
dialogs.translated: Yeah, him. He wanted to do it as soon as he heard the proclamation, but then groaned and swore he would see her tomorrow.

dialogs.original: Well, well; as for him, he brought his disease    hither: here he does but repair it.   I know he will    come in our shadow, to scatter his crowns in the    sun.
dialogs.translated: Well, well, as for himhe brought his disease here, and he just keeps it up. I know he'll come here soon and that he'll spend plenty of money.

dialogs.original: Well, if we had of every nation a traveller, weshould lodge them with this sign.
dialogs.translated: Well, if we had customers from every country in the world, we'd welcome them in, since they either have syphilis or will do soon.

dialogs.original: [To MARINA]    Pray you, come hither awhile. You    have fortunes coming upon you.   Mark me: you must    seem to do that fearfully which you commit    willingly, despise profit where you have most gain.    To weep that you live as ye do makes pity in your    lovers: seldom but that pity begets you a good    opinion, and that opinion a mere profit.
dialogs.translated: [To MARINA] Come here for a minute. Good things are coming your way. Mark my words: you need to pretend you're afraid of having sex even though you're perfectly willing, and you need to seem like you don't want the money, even though you'll make a fortune. If you cry about having to work as a prostitute, your customers will take pity on you; pity equals good reviews, and good reviews equals a huge profit.

dialogs.original: I understand you not.
dialogs.translated: I don't understand you.

dialogs.original: O, take her home, mistress, take her home: theseblushes of hers must be quenched with some present practise.
dialogs.translated: Oh, take her home, mistress, take her home. We'll get rid of all this shyness with a little practice.

dialogs.original: Thou sayest true, i' faith, so they must; for yourbride goes to that with shame which is her way to gowith warrant.
dialogs.translated: You're right, darn it, we will. Even brides are afraid of the wedding night, though they have no reason to be.

dialogs.original: 'Faith, some do, and some do not. But, mistress, ifI have bargained for the joint,
dialogs.translated: Well, some do, some don't. But, mistress, since it's me that bought her

dialogs.original: Thou mayst cut a morsel off the spit.
dialogs.translated: you can have a little taste.

dialogs.original: I may so.
dialogs.translated: I may?

dialogs.original: Who should deny it? Come, young one, I like themanner of your garments well.
dialogs.translated: Who's stopping you?[To MARINA] Cheer up, missy. I like your clothes.

dialogs.original: Ay, by my faith, they shall not be changed yet.
dialogs.translated: Ah, don't change them yet.

dialogs.original: Boult, spend thou that in the town: report what a    sojourner we have; you'll lose nothing by custom.    When nature flamed this piece, she meant thee a good    turn; therefore say what a paragon she is, and thou    hast the harvest out of thine own report.
dialogs.translated: [She gives BOULT a coin] Boult, spread the news in town about our new guest, and don't leave out a single detail. When Mother Nature put together this girl, she meant to do you a favor. If you tell everyone how beautiful she is, you'll get money and you'll get to sleep with her, too.

dialogs.original: I warrant you, mistress, thunder shall not so awakethe beds of eels as my giving out her beauty stir upthe lewdly-inclined. I'll bring home some to-night.
dialogs.translated: I promise I'll excite those dirty-minded men as much as I can. I'll bring some home tonight.

dialogs.original: Come your ways; follow me.
dialogs.translated: Come on, then, follow me.

dialogs.original: If fires be hot, knives sharp, or waters deep,Untied I still my virgin knot will keep.Diana, aid my purpose!
dialogs.translated: I swear I'll stay a virgin! Diana, help me!

dialogs.original: What have we to do with Diana? Pray you, will you go with us?
dialogs.translated: What do we have to do with Diana? Now will you come with us?
